VrgXIykFFwRUXHq0RyJonw.text: Wonderful healthy delicious food. Had the tomato starter and pea salad starter. Both yummy. Husband had cod. I had risotto. Very tasty and wholesome. Finished with honey ice cream:  also delicious. Nice decor. Would definitely go back.

9yDTcTas-aMw0tZQU6KKZw.text: top end dining, very intense flavours, stunning and stylish portions, desert was spectacular. I took clients here and the menu went down extremely well. expensive but impressive, and the house champagne was of good quality and not a rip off. will be back when the expense acct allows

8Wk2VddDJBoer8Py6VQyxQ.text: Wild Honey is an excellent restaurant. The menu is stylistically like that of its sister Arbutus and just as competently executed: fresh, simple fare, daintily presented, creative but not remotely eccentric. There's a lot more atmosphere and intimacy than Arbutus, thanks to the wood panelled, dark interior. The cheeseboard is first-rate. We had impeccable service. The waiter showed enthusiasm, real expertise about cheese and a clear passion for it, and his appearances at the table were timely. The wine list is thoughtful and interesting, and the prices very reasonable considering what they're like in London. Highly recommended.

Ew__llH6MnzMfcfMzjkG_A.text: I Know its a bit trendy right now, and the chef is getting a few excitable reviews but Wild Honey was pretty forgettable. if you want an oak paneled dining room go to the much better Galvin Bistrot de Luxe or even Automat. If you want food like this go to every other mid range modern resteraunt. In fairness, they did offer pigs head which I should have really tried, and that would have made it more memorable. Service was pleasant if a little rushed. Its fine, just not special enough. zzzzzzzzzzzzz

OOZ-01jVcNiu-eG-D1Suvg.text: Wild Honey felt more gentleman's club than restaurant and the tables were packed too close together where we were sat. I preferred the atmosphere and decor at Arbutus. However, I really enjoyed my smoked eel starter (that was a first for me) and the very tender veal that followed as my main course. With all the choice of great places to eat in London, I'm not sure this would be at the top of my list for a return visit.

ZBPRXUG8NWTe-V0meAPQ1w.text: Decent. The Bearnaise sauce with the USDA 28 day aged American rib beef was simply excellent. The veal ravioli was ok. The wine selection was good, had a good mimosa-house-sepcial cocktail (prosecco and blood-orange juice), a good champagne ()Moutard, NV, Brut Grande Cuvee), the table bread was good, the veal ravioli I had with a German Pinot Noir (Spatburgunder MayerNakel, Ahr (2007), very nice, the rib-beef I had with Edmeades Zinfandel, Mendocino (Mendocino wines are so so so good), Then I had a royal cheese fest, with Epoisses Affine , Fourme D'ambert blue, Cathare (brie style goat cheese), Fleur De Chevre, fribourg d'estive (fribourg canton gruyere), and a few others paird off with tawny port and a plate of honey, and for dessert I had the honey ice cream paired with a Sauternes (Satelnau de Sduirant, 2002). Very good, if you come here, you are coming to drink like a maniac (and don't get bottles for the love of christ, pair your wines) and enjoy the divine cheese selection.

MNJHawGT_J9Qgt_bkfczGw.text: We had dinner at Wild Honey last night. The saddle of rabbit was superb, as was the rest of the meal. And the service was as good as the meal itself. We sat at the bar and were well taken care of all evening by both the bartender and the waiters. They were knowledgeable, attentive, funny and helpful, and we were even served some delicious foie gras and another appetizer, on the house, while we waited for our slightly delayed main course to arrive. Thank you for a memorable evening!

SJxM87qiBwE24buCQK83Ng.text: My mother and I came straight from a weekend in Paris to lunch at Wild Honey, toting luggage and in casual travel clothes.  Two concerns should be immediately apparent.  First, would we be judged for looking a proper mess?  Second, would the food be palatable after all the divine eats Paris had to offer?Thankfully, the answers were no, and yes, in that order.  The ambience, at least for lunch, was relaxed, and the service was helpful and courteous throughout.  The food managed to please our spoiled taste buds as well.The space is charming, very classic and dark-wood, but with whimsical artwork lightening up the walls and atmosphere.  I was afraid I would feel unrelaxed based on reviews, but it felt casual and leisurely enough.  I can see how the personality of the place might change with sundown, though, so maybe hold the denim shorts for dinner.Wild Honey offers a prix fixe 3-course lunch for £18.95 with two options for each course.  My mother and I went with prix fixe and a la carte and shared, as I was set on trying a specific dessert.We ordered the gazpacho appetizer, the risotto of smoked eel, and the classic custard tart from the prix fixe menu, and the organic salmon and wild honey ice cream a la carte.The gazpacho was a zesty refreshing bowl of orange-red interspersed with green peas and alfalfa sprouts.  The soup itself was a balanced blend of red pepper and tomato with a nice dice of onion, very flavorful and very good.  The "Loch Duart" salmon with Jersey Royal potatoes and young market vegetables (peas, fava beans, carrots, beets, leeks, purslane) was simply cooked and gently sauced with pleasant results.  The bright green risotto of smoked eel with sorrel and sour cream, on the other hand, was not good.  The menu as written suffered from something of a lack of detail, and it failed to mention that the entire dish was drowned in pork fat.  My mother doesn't eat pork and said she wanted to spit out the first bite.  I love pork in all its forms, though, and even I found the stench overwhelming.  The eel didn't help much, as it was oversmoked to the point of acridity, somehow emphasizing the general aura of bacon in the dish.  If this sounds good to you, trust me, I heart bacon.  This was too much.Dessert was another story and deserves its own paragraph.  The classic custard tart that sounded so boring on the prix fixe menu was absolutely fantastic.  The first thing we noticed was its seductive wiggle as our server put it down on the table.  It came on a thin crust served with plump juicy soaked raisins.  The taste impressed with flavors of gingerbread mixed with the light cold creaminess of the custard, enhanced all the more by the raisins.  The wild honey ice cream with crushed honeycomb lit up every tasting nerve in my head.  Three shapely quenelles on a small bed of crunchy honeycomb - simple, elegant, phenomenal.  This was one of the best desserts of our London trip, and one of the best I've ever had.  The fact that my mother actually preferred the custard tart should indicate its high caliber as well.  Do not skip dessert at this restaurant.I left Wild Honey happy with the sweet bold taste of honey playing on my tongue.  Even with the misstep of the fat-drenched risotto, the meal was great.  For a Michelin-starred restaurant, prices were also reasonable, especially the prix fixe.  I would highly recommend this place to anyone living nearby, and might even consider going back for that ice cream on a future trip.

3FWWomkZQMN88xOTFEwKvw.text: eh, i was a bit underwhelmed.i came here w/ my parents last night.  the decor is old school w/ wood paneling on the walls.  the clientele is on the old(er) school side as well.to start, we had the dorset crab w/ bitter leaves and lychee and the mackerel w/ beets and radish.  both were pretty good and a decent size for sharing.  presentation was pretty.for my main course, i had the bouillabaise, my mom got the plaice, and my dad got the cod and octopus.  my dad's cod was tiny, so i gave him some of my bouillabaise, which had 3 big pieces of fish.  it was "traditional marsailles style," which i actually had never had before.  this meant that the fish and the soup were served separately.  the flavor was good, but i kind of wish there were more seafood in there other than just fish.the desserts were delicious.  we got the pear clafoutis (to compare w/ the one we recently had in paris) and the honey ice cream, which was lovely.  service was weird here.  they would bring dishes to us w/o really saying a word, take them away, and then just leave.

rdyXX9vo5-oMnjkBJln3gQ.text: 4.5 stars rounded up to five because I think on another try it would be truly 5. Very cozy, lovely, and bustling. The sort of place you could see yourself going to a lot. Not the least bit pretentious and all the waiters seemed in good spirits. The 3 course lunch is amazing value, as many have pointed out. I chose the fish appetiser and the fish main, which came with the delicious green risotto. The fish was fresh and cooked perfectly; very flavorful. I think the risotto had quite a bit of cream, but it was good and hey, you have to splurge on the calories once in a while. The cheese course was nice and the jam very tasty. Food came out fairly quickly, which is good for lunch when time can be an issue. I would definitely go back.

6R9rre2kgg7WZB280zyfdA.text: The set lunch is an amazing deal at something like 16.95 ish. The best meal I had during my 5-day stay in London.Salmon salad - this was truly excellent.Slow-braised lamb shank - mmm. Mmm. Mm. The very-green risotto that came out had a surprisingly grassy taste.  For some reason, this didn't translate into icky.  It tasted fresh...and good. Floating island in custard - very sweet but sure satisfies a dessert craving.Good service.The only 'complaint' I have is that the bread was unremarkable.

d-gGY5b9JItdCUEWiNHdRQ.text: One of my favorite french restaruants in London. I have never had a bad taste in my mouth there. You can't go there without getting 3 courses, the menu is changed every season. If you are not a fan of smelly cheese, when you reserve your table tell them to sit you away from the cheese table.

CYzwAN64ji2X5Oquw3xT3w.text: Wild Honey is a little gourmet haven for the well-heeled in between Regent St and Bond St, so perfect for post-hard days' shopping (although probably book ahead). Cosy, elegant wood panelled dining room with one of those menus where you want to order everything (French influence eg rabbit etc. and lots of buttery yummy jus). The wild honey ice cream to cleanse the palate is definitely the way to go. (Monikasays.com)

_rPv9BkYIOealMDvkwgVBQ.text: Went for a casual lunch.  because we only reserved day-of, they only had bar seating available, which was fine for this lunch.  Food was outstanding and the bartender was helpful.  I had the lamb and my guest had the beef.  both were excellent, and very flavorful.  sides were also tasty. would recommend more for a business or formal lunch.

46FQxGCJsFmyihY6Blkn1A.text: I came here two years ago and still remember my meal to be one of the best I have ever had. The highlights of my meal were the pumpkin risotto for dinner - served in a beautiful copper pot and the decadent chocolate soup for desert. The staff was friendly and resourceful. I cannot wait until I am in London again for another meal here.

hEn0wrFkLW57-mp2R9_LAQ.text: One of my go-to places when I want to treat myself to a good meal or have an occasion to hit the expense account.  The service is good (a rarity in this country!), food is yummy and wine/cocktail selection is solid. Great ambience too!

0Kk3MsxjtXikqk8Kw44acA.text: Went for Sunday lunch here to take advantage of the set menu deal (just under £20 for 3 courses) and was really impressed. Whilst the tables might have been a bit too close together during an evening service, the restaurant was quiet enough on a Sunday to mean that this wasn't a problem. I was particularly impressed that wine was available in carafes at a pro-rata rate to the whole bottle, and the food itself was delicious.

wQZGF-QFyc3ZHxZBQTLF_w.text: I recently went to Wild Honey with my boyfriend- we have been to Arbitus a few time before so were keen to try it out. I'm not sure whether it is down to the age of the clientele (we were the youngest people there by about twenty years) of the oak-paneled interior of the restaurant, but i feels a lot more 'grown up' and smart than its Soho sister, Arbitus. I actually prefer the atmosphere in WIld Honey. Whilst it is very traditional and almost feels quite conservative, we never felt uneasy or uncomfortable.The waiters made us feel entirely at ease, helping us with the menu and making suggestions from the wine menu (thank god)  The tarte tatin was incredible- an entire pan was brought over to the table filled with the most moist apples and delicate pastry. I think it was meant for 4 people, but the two of us ate it all happily.

aKprphMngxHlAD7c6jjSwQ.text: LOVED wild honey!!! best cod EVER w/mussels & chorizo (prob bc all the other cod i've ever had was in fried fish&chips). i was looking fwd to their beef tartar w/egg but wasn't on the menu. the crab w/guac was a nice starter nonetheless. also a plus that the service was AMAZING & the atmosphere was nice but not too stuffy (esp for a 1 michelin * restaurant)

dgVdgR1P3QvuvG9BcXTuqA.text: When Wild Honey first opened to rave reviews, I couldn't wait to try it out as being a fan of Arbutus (its sister restaurant in Soho) I wanted to see if it even compared. The interior of Wild Honey is simple but stylish, with sleek polished wooden tables and soft upholstered seating.  Like Arbutus, a key objective is the use of the freshest ingredients according to season to produce high quality, well planned out dishes, but at a good price. The menu is constantly changing according to the availability of the ingredients. Anything they cook with pork I tend to order. I just can not resist, especially when pork belly is on the menu as they cook it slowly, ensuring the meat is succulent and simply melts into your mouth with every bite.Also, like Arbutus, you can have any wine you want served in 250ml carafes, which means you don't have to indulge in a whole bottle each time you want to try out  different wine.They do a delicious 3 course lunch menu for £16.95 and a 3 course set dinner for £18.95. Be sure to book as seats get zapped up fast.

auHOghhYqEQu1Ngc0GnUrA.text: For a business lunch venue in central London, Wild Honey does the job. The food was good (I had the rabbit saddle and a dessert), the service was efficient and not too pushy. The decor is not very welcoming though as the place is quite dark and the wood panels make the room more reminiscent of a library in Cambridge than a contemporary restaurant in Mayfair. Not much buzz, the place is quiet but lacks atmosphere I thought. They have a small set menu at £16.5 which sounds like good value, otherwise lunch with 2 courses plus water plus coffee is around £35. In summary a decent venue for a business lunch but I am not sure I will be back as I cant think of a really good reason to do so.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom

HyjAIseFM02BrwSDqHKjBA.text: Amazing meal.  We ate family style sampling everyone's dishes and all were a hit.

daoP9IVgfz0i1gMqMRoX0A.text: Went here on a Monday evening, after seeing a recommendation on Yelp. Arrived at around 8pm, the restaurant was nearly full. Clientele seemed to be mainly regulars and the odd straggler shopper like me. The staff were very friendly and accomodating and the menu was short and interesting. My wife and I shared a starter (snails) very yummy. I had the cod which was slightly undercooked (as suggested) and equally delicious. We concluded the meal with Clafoutis (a custard, Yorkshire puddingy type thingy) which was the final piece in the Jigsaw. What a wonderful meal, great service and friendly too. Can't wait to visit the sister restaurant Arbutus, in Frith St

5epnvrvy6AusgAQM16LJEA.text: the bread here was really really good. the main course- duck, was far too salty and i thoguht instead of really going for the flavors, they just cranked up teh salt. so that was good but definitely a downside. the desserts, however, was a full five stars. wild honey ice cream and honeycomb... wow!!! and floating island was great too. great price for the pre theatre menu

SAaxq-3cvUYnDzFIpCuLzg.text: I had a very enjoyable dinner here on my last trip to London. We had reservations for 9:30 pm and despite the late hour the service team was very nice and did not rush us out the door. I had a delicious foie gras terrine and a main course of deer. For dessert, I had the honey ice cream with honeycomb. Everything was prepared well and it was a solid overall meal. My wife and our friends also seemed pleased with their dishes. As at Arbutus, they have a good selection of wine by the glass, quartino, and bottle which I appreciate.Wild Honey isn't unique and nothing you'll eat there will push any boundaries, but it is a solid, enjoyable restaurant where one can have a nice meal at a reasonable price.

B7Z3wGVsM2EdtjI-Ww_2sQ.text: I do love a bit of fine dining but don't go too often, mainly because the cost is so prohibitive. I love the food and wine but do baulk a bit at paying £80/£100/... a head too frequently. There are more cost effective ways to eat at such establishments though as most provide set lunches of some description, handy for ladies that lunch but not ideal if you have to work office hours as I do. We needed somewhere to dine yesterday though as a colleague is leaving and so decided to give one a go. Being based in Mayfair the choice is fairly large but we decided upon Wild Honey, a Michelin starred establishment from the same stable as Arbutus, a Soho establishment known for great value fine dining. At £18.95 for 3 courses for lunch it seemed a bargain, even if drinking was obviously going to have a fairly negative effect upon the bill. You have to sacrifice a bit for these set lunches with a reduced choice (two options per course) and a reduced portion size too, not that it was too obvious with the dessert. Our choices were potato soup or pork slices with apple puree for starter, Cornish mullet with potato gnocchi or lasagna of veal shoulder for main and a pain perdu with seville marmalade or a portion of Brie de Meaux for dessert. Starting off we all went for pork, as nice as I'm sure their potato soup would be it was just never going to compete with four men at the table. The dish was rolled belly pork, braised and then sliced very thinly. Apple puree provided some tart sweetness and the baby herbs some pepperiness. As much as there things to like about this dish, such as the beautiful texture and the apple puree, I was a little disappointed all told. The meat was bland in parts with the seasoning concentrated in spots, one mouthful was woefully underseasoned with the next an explosion of salt in the mouth. It was nice, don't get me wrong, but nothing too special. Again the meat won for the second course with four orders of the lasagna of veal shoulder. Whilst more a ragu between two sheets of pasta, constructed post cooking rather than baked, this was nothing short of amazing. Without a doubt the finest ragu and pasta to ever pass my lips. The pasta was delicately thin but still toothsome. The ragu was rich, meaty and seasoned to perfection, melt in the mouth veal with cubes of vegetables which at first resisted the squash of the tongue against the palate (there was really no need to go so far as chewing) before giving way in a little burst of sweetness. Superlative. No one was too keen on brie, de Meaux or not, so we made a pact to share a proper cheeseboard after our dessert and kept up the theme by all ordering the pain perdu, seville marmalade. The pain perdu (eggy bread) was good but not perfect. Everything stuffed in the mouth at once Masterchef judge style made for a pleasant dessert, the sweet ice cream and bread being a good foil to the bitter seville orange. The pain perdu on its own though had a bit of a bitter taste, as if over caramelised I think. A slightly tough bottom edge suggested a little overcooking on one side too. There wasn't a scrap left on any of our plates by the end though which says something. The cheeseboard was an on display affair, sat proudly in the middle of the restaurant right behind us and I got the pleasure of choosing. We had a bleu d'Auvergne, a Montgomery's cheddar, Epoisse and then another blue and another washed rind whose names completely evade me now. All were fine examples, nutty for the washed rind, fantastically mature for the cheddar and smooth and salty for the blue. Throughout the meal we were also given masses of very good sourdough bread, so much that I had to stop taking it after a while. With two bottles of wine between four and cheese it came in about £40 a head, a step up from the £16 food bill but not bad for food like this, when they got it right that is. It has definitely made me want to go back and give the a la carte menu a go, something I think would only add maybe £20 a head to the bill, which thinking how impressive some of the mains around us were looking doesn't sound too bad at all. Photos of the food can be seen here: cookingthebooks.typepad.…

nE7FYepWlUz5Sd_9pGO3ZA.text: I heard about Wild Honey because it was awarded a Michelin star in 2008. I made reservations for my girlfriend and I on a trip to London earlier this summer and we had a great time. I'm not sure where all the negative reviews are coming from, but I found them to be very courteous and expedient. The pork belly appetizer and the lamb entree were amazing, but the honeycomb ice cream stole the show.Best of all, the prices were extremely reasonable! I would recommend this place to all of my friends.

_3CHnGdDXnp_Pysy2-0GTA.text: First time, last time. Crab starter was great and made the subsequent course an even greater disappointment. The veal was so overcooked and dry as to be inedible. The beef was tough to the point of also being inedible - it struck me that the cut of beef needed to be cooked longer and in a very different manner to help break it down.  I mentioned the veal to the waiter when he was running the credit card (and asked how the meal was for the first time). The manger did follow up as we left.Shame really, nice interior and great location. I will stick with Bellamy's (they were closed).

qZGzllkD-dMSab2XIwNVSQ.text: Wild Honey was the first place I went upon arriving in London. After seeing that it had received a Michelin star in the past, and it's sinfully yummy-looking menu, I was sold. Between the not-so-friendly hostess and completely unorganized/inexperienced servers behind the bar, I would say that they could probably stand to improve a bit in the service realm. But the food was delicious, and very flavorful across the board. I did the prix fixe with a glass of red recommended by the staff. Though I couldn't tell you what the wine was, I do know he chose well for my food selections. To start, I had the eel and chicken terrine with a fruit relish to balance the saltiness -- it was absolutely delicious. So tasty, and definitely my favorite part of the meal. I was curious to try the ox tongue with polenta, and upon first bite was pleasantly surprised. As I continued eating though, I realized after the first few bites that the greens were terribly over-salted, and the creaminess of the ox and polenta left my tongue screaming for something to cut the richness a bit. Very tasty, but just too much, and my main reason for not giving a full 5 stars. And to finish, the meringue with custard could only be facetiously described by an American as a marshmallow flavored soup. Good, but not my usual cup of tea for dessert. As far as ambiance, I did enjoy the establishment itself, though the bar is situated along the main, narrow walkway into the back dining room, which is bothersome. I was also noticeably in the minority, as the only female patron I saw for a good while. Interesting, though not unsettling. Clearly a great place for business lunches. I wouldn't make it a priority to return, personally.

LhJyHNa8cJNo7vxp5Qs7uA.text: My experience tonight at Wild Honey was slightly mixed unfortunately. The food overall was pretty good, even if the main course of brill was served a bit cold in the middle. The servers were not very attentive so for example we had to chase the bread and we were asked multiple times as to whether we were looking to order drinks. The place wasn't that busy but the service lacked the joined up-ness that you would expect at these prices. The dessert selection of petit fours were delicious as was the honeycomb ice cream. The wine list offered not a great deal at the more reasonable end of the spectrum - in the case of the reds just a few wines at £30 before ascending to aGeorgian wine and a Romanian wine that many would know nothing about, before hitting the near £60 price bracket. It is not for a second that we had a bad meal, more that I was possibly expecting more and didn't get it.

BTW0udDpm1NKRJn9euinKg.text: Fabulous dinner in a fun but not obnoxiously loud environment. Staff was really obliging with letting us try a few wines before settling on a bottle and the food was outstanding all around. Will be back!

Crwwnxs9ksDomOw7n9QS4w.text: We stumbled on Wild Honey while I was teaching in London for a week. The meal was excellent, we shared the beef for two and a particularly nice bottle of wine. Ice cream was the dessert of choice, as other reviews mention. The honeycombs do have a unique flavor that may not appeal to everyone. In sum, this was a quality experience from start to finish. With the exchange rate our meal was pricey but that was largely due to the wine selection.

5VrzjR02Y5IvbKznqglEsw.text: Always a delight. Always fresh. Menu always has new and innovative dishes. Staff is friendly.  You can return again and again.

_B214PalQV10_BJVtmJ1yQ.text: Totally terrible experience. Not sure why this place has a Michelin star the food was cold (3 courses, the pork belly starter, the plaice and the cod) and undercooked (artichoke).The main redeeming feature was the service, the host was very apologetic and took money off the bill. Whilst she was very keen to try and persuade us to come back the clincher was when she finished by saying come back when 2 specific chefs were working as that is when we would have a better food experience. Sorry but if you are a Michelin starred restaurant shouldn't all your chefs be able to cook?

d3wUD6xDEq91gdo8LMbNvw.text: Bad service attitude, their tried to be "french" attitude but the staff is in general from Baltic countries so it gets more horrible experience. Decor is actually very nice, oak. Food is quiet expensive for what you get, its out of flavor tasteless mediocre. No thanks not again rather go to another place,

7kB9_c2HO7T-bxitoux-ZA.text: Having lunched at Arbutus, we were keen to try Wild Honey for dinner. We walked in without reservations and were seated at the bar, which was fine because all the other twentysomethings were at the bar. As a reknown fine dining establishment, Wild Honey certainly looks the part with dark brown walls, but a few paintings add youthful vigor to the scene.The service was attentive and it was nice to see the manager working the room and making sure everyone was happy. I for one was happy to find wild honey ice cream on honey crumble on the dessert menu after a delicious meal of game. I was also pleasantly surprised to find Molton Brown products and Dyson air blades in the loo. Wild Honey, you certainly pull out all the stops. I'm a big fan.

bukLqJvBCDQKlq9-LrfnXA.text: I came here for my good friends birthday, so it was a celebratory affair. She had been to its sister restaurant, Arbitus in Soho, and this is the Mayfair version. I'm used to my restaurants being a bit more scruffy, and I am a bit of a scruff-bag anyway so when I walked into this grownup, sophisticated room I felt a bit out of place for a second, but the staff were all very welcoming and friendly. Our table wasn't ready so we sat at the bar, ordered champagne and people watched. I took a look around and decided that this was a very elegant place. The walls are all dark oak panelled, and modern art is dotted around. There are a few dark comfy booths, which due to the size of our party, we were able to take. The food was modern British eclectic, definitely haute cuisine. Because I am a penniless little scruff-bag, I was relieved to see that there is a 3 course set menu for 16.95. I had a carrot veloute for a starter which came with toasted hazelnuts  and olives, and a smoked eel risotto for a main. The portions certainly aren't large, but I made up for that by diving for the bread basket a couple of times. Dessert was cheese from the large cheeseboard which makes up the centre of the room. I thought my meal was delicious, but I wish the menu was slightly more affordable so that I could check out the other dishes. Or I wish I was richer, one or the other would be good.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom

TRZOJ_mAbyJftJf_7RusDw.text: My first yelp review since moving from San Francisco (the land of yelp!) to London!Wild Honey was wonderful. While I haven't gotten used to British pacing (sooooo slow compared to anywhere in the US...I've realized this is just how things are here though, not particular to this establishment), food-wise everything was top-notch.The standout starter was the salad of Autumn squash with goat curd and muscat grapes-- simple and delicious.I had a line caught plaice with swiss chard and I devoured it. My dad had veal with caramelized onions and spelt, and he also really loved his entree. My last note is that the Wild Honey Ice Cream with crushed honeycomb is divine. So far, this has been the best meal I've had in London.

ILPK7Ly7bcWR3aCr2Ht-EA.text: Loved this place. Great service. Dishes prepared by a Chef. Beautiful and delicious. Had the Turbo entree and honey ice cream for dessert.

ZCKS3DUqvAJ6kOPPa3zoEA.text: For Sunday lunch they only do a prix fix at £25 each.  I wasn't enamored with the staff today they just didn't seem as friendly as usual.  Food was delicious as always though.  Chicken wings and macaroni with cream taragon and sweetcorn was heavenly as was my pear tart/ cake thing.May be just an off day.  May be I am just being picky today.

zwPiEQ3jUfTPJmCaa4LtsA.text: I took my Mama here for Mother's Day dinner. The way I feel I can sum up this restaurant is through song lyrics. The song that plays in 'Pulp Fiction' of "Girl, you'll be a woman soon". This is the best way to design the cuisine of Wild Honey. It is going through puberty and is working past the feelings of being embarrassed if someone says the word "mastication" but meets more of an eye roll and the wanting to feel more grown up. Yet there is still a slight infantile element to how things are expressed. Yet a desire to be viewed as a grown up, but one with spots and braces. I felt the service in this place was a disappointment and not what you would expect from a Michelin starred establishment. Firstly they were a bit vague about my reservation so already we were off to a slightly clunky start. Next point of issue was asking for drinks. I felt we were being rushed a bit and there wasn't the greatest sense of hospitality in place and a rushed feeling for us to have decided what we wanted to eat within seconds of looking at the menu. The third thing that annoyed me was the way the bread was presented and served. It was literally big slightly asymmetrical slices of either white or brown sour dough that you grabbed from a basket they offered you. There was no nice spoon and fork way of serving the bread. Maybe I sound a bit of a pedant but in a Michelin starred place I like there to be a nice way to greet people and a slightly more eloquent way of presenting and serving the bread. If it means I am a bread bully then so be it. There also wasn't an amuse bouche but an emerging unamused boy. I know which one I would opt for. To start with I had a guinea fowl and foie gras boudin blanc. This was served with a small salad and some intensely and delicately cut vegetables. I loved it. There was a nice mixture of textures, all the flavours balanced and I felt myself wanting more. It was also reasonably priced. My beloved had the smoked eel with a smoked turnip and alphonso mango puree Mother had the pork belly with snails. Both of their dishes displayed some wonderful technical skills, great flavours, fantastic seasoning but it wasn't anything that left me feeling that there was a great culinary flare in place. This gut instinct was confirmed when we had our mains. My Mother and I had the rabbit which was served two ways which consisted of two discs of rabbit wrapped in pancetta and cooked with rabbit liver on the inside. This lacked a certain sweetness and left me with a rather bitter aftertaste which over powered the delicacy of the rabbit. The vegetables were wonderful as well as the saddle of rabbit that was slow cooked with this. There was also interesting flavour and texture offered from having olives and hazelnuts cooked with them. The sauce had a good depth of flavour too but was a bit greasy. It was almost split yet tasted nice so I will forgive that. But there were some technical errors such as one of the two discs being slightly undercooked and a slight lack of umami. There would be no foodgasm for me tonight. My partner ordered the rose veal which was served with soft polenta and some slightly unidentifiable cabbage/kale. It was nicely cooked but just bland. She found it uninspiring. I found looking at it to be a bit depressing. It was like Monday morning on a plate. Mother wasn't overly impressed with hers nor was I with mine. I also found the way the waiting staff leaned over us a bit excessive and it lacked a finesse. Perhaps they need to watch Albert Roux Jr's programme 'Service' to learn a trick or two...failing that a whole new staff training manual. That would be my suggestion. There was a wonderful wine list but a slight lack of sommelier. But I will give Wild Honey some credit and that is you can buy wine by the carafe as well as bottle and the prices aren't too much of a smack in the mouth. The selection available is very comprehensive and there is something on there to suit every taste and budget. We decided with dessert to sample a little of what they had to offer. I opted for a glass of Ice Cider and my partner chose some Tokaji in a taster size. Well that's what we ordered. The waiter seemed a bit perplexed that we were ordering in such a way but at the same time if you have those types of options available to customers on the menu then be prepared for such a request. When it arrived we realised how generous the dessert wine 'taster' size was. Take Note: Order taster size if you are having dessert wine there as you will save cash and have the right amount of the wine to have with your dessert. There was a slight error initially in the fact that we had all the same wine but to their credit they rectified it promptly. For desserts we shared the wild honey ice cream and honeycomb as well as a pear clafoutis with custard. The ice cream was delicately made and had a gentle flavour. Only that mixed with honeycomb in theory

Xan5bxr18itVZKSFT3IZdw.text: I am going to go again because I didn't get enough of the full experience to determine if it had 5 star status.  It was hard to get the full atmosphere of the place because it was a relatively quiet night and we were tucked away in a giant booth which was fabulous for a good catchup with my friend.  No noise to contend with and no distractions.  The restaurant is nice--lots of wood, high ceilings--you just melt into the booth cushions.  I loved the nice table in the middle which was the cheese serving station and I adored the fact that the gentlemen waitstaff were dressed sharply in dress slacks and nice button-down shirts.  Snazzy touch, Wild Honey!The food was very good--there were so many amazing-sounding appetizers that I opted for two instead of a main.  I feasted on an onion tartlet with artic char and creme fraiche which was delicious and dorset crab salad with apricots and an avocado puree.  Both were extremely tasty.  And of course we had the wild honey ice cream with honeycomb which was divine.  I am looking forward to going back....this is a very good find.

8KLlMxlkmrf1UqV5cR_7aA.text: I always ask myself if it is possible to rate a Michelin star restaurant less than five stars. After all a professional inspector gave the place a prestigious award after numerous visits. But then I remind myself to rate within its category. The category Wild Honey is in is restaurants awarded one Michelin Star. Long story short, Wild Honey is great and presents my kind of menu and I'd love to come back here on any occasion. The menu features locally sourced food obtained in what appears to be a sustainable manner. I enjoyed the line caught mackerel but thought the presentation and other components on the dish were a bit off. How dressed up can mackerel served cold be? Norfolk hare was wild and came with a warning that it, along with the other game could contain shot in it. There is something intriguing about thinking how the animal you are about to eat was hunted in the wild as opposed to raised on a farm. I could definitely taste the difference between this rabbit and the farm raised variety; so much more flavor. The hare was cooked perfectly and spaetzle with veg in it accompanied the protein well. The only disappointment was the wild honey comb ice cream. Somehow the honey combs were crisped. The combs and ice cream left a bad taste on my pallet. At Wild Honey its all about the food on the plate and the food is what I enjoy most.

A-ua9HS2Y4i7L4-g7tAPYw.text: I like this place. This place is not too pretentious yet quite elegant. It can also be quite sh eek depending on what you wanna get out of it.Anyway I loved the staff. They were friendly nice and very kewl. Being in London, they delivered very good customer service which I though was a fantastic achievement in itself. I got the eel as the appetizer. The eel in it self was quite tasty. I thought the sauces could have been a bit more flavourful. There were some fried bits to this appetizer which I did not care for too much.I got the Cod as an on tray.  It reminded me a lot about home cooked Catalan food. This dish was all about the flavour of the fish with minimal spice to it. The problem was, the fish did not seem fresh ( today's catch ) so you do get the fishy taste to it. I think this dish had a good approach but the flavours needed to be balanced a bit.I got the chocolate soup. This dessert was awesome !!! I loved it. Plus the lovely staff who served us, made this dinner very enjoyable.

Xoluenr2HXr3SCJe_9sSIw.text: So it's pretty clear that I lived and/or worked in Mayfair for a while based on my reviews. I mostly just ate there!!Wild Honey is a great place to take the parents when they're visiting London. It is quiet and intimate and the food is phenomenal. Truly a wonderful experience all around.A MUST: (I'll start with the end...) you have to order the homemade ice cream. It was supreme. No words can properly describe it - and that's coming from an ice cream connoisseur!I had the beef, which was delicious. My parents each had fish - cod and sea bass - and both were also well presented and tasty. Our appetizers - a mix of salads and soups were all nice portions and worthy of the price/Michelin star.My only gripe is that the service is a bit slow, but you are in Britain after all! This is the kind of place where you want to enjoy your meal slowly so being rushed would have ruined it. Enjoy the slowness!

dnVMYP7b1kt1rIK5mqAguA.text: What a delightful little restaurant. Anthony Demetre's cosy venture, tucked away at the east-end of Mayfair is a refreshing change to the often pretentious chique of French establishments in this part of London. Instead of pompous, stiff waiters who you normally pay to look down on you throughout the meal, the front of house at Wild Honey are friendly, relaxed yet sufficiently attentive. Wild Honey feels very British from the moment you enter the dark Oak-panelled dining room. It looks like the club house of a gentlemen's shooting club. Come to think of it, hanging carcasses wouldn't look out of place here (and would be a welcome replacement to the questionable modern-art on the walls). We opted for the set menu, which at £18 for three courses is surely one of the best-value Michelin lunches in the capital. The a la carte is also reasonably priced but all set-menu dishes appealed on this visit. A starter of sliced pork and apple puree with capers was light and refreshing and a main of roast chicken with gnocchi and chanterelles was packed with flavour and accompanied by a deliciously rich sauce. To finish, a classic Pain Perdu was cooked perfectly with tasty, light bread and the right balance of sweetness in the sauce. Coffee here was excellent but does not come with petit fours. In fact no freebies were offered throughout the meal which was slightly disappointing but not surprising given the price.The wine selection is relatively small but well-priced with mark-ups around 100%. Chakana Torrontes from Argentina for example was £19.50 instead of £8-£9 in most shops. Overall, this was a very enjoyable meal and I shall be back soon to try the famous Bouillabaisse.

0eJH908Jk9uq0xsuUjxdjQ.text: The very best type of restaurant: cozy, but elegant. Great food and even better service. Selective drinks menu / wine list. My companion and I did the tasting menu and everything was delicious. Will come back on every trip to London!

EMaGb5TvlBStreIbRUWKOA.text: Not good value for money, poor service, deserted by 9.15 pm on a Monday evening except for the 2 or 3 mice running around the restaurant.

kqBghJSwVUAt6k92aihZ0A.text: This restaurant came highly recommended by the manager of our hotel. It did not disappoint. You can tell that they take great care and attention to detail in every facet of the business. The staff couldn't have done a better job. I highly recommend the beef tenderloin or the slow cooked Denbighshire lamb. Both were absolutely magical dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom

mKbO4s0ChTPS1mtYa5W5jw.text: Great lunch spot! They had exotic dishes.. the special was hare. I wasn't going to order a poor lil bunny rabbit but the server highly recommended it. It was so good. My partner also enjoyed his beef dish that was slow cooked all day long.

kQsyT3vrSHvZdfPmG9a2Mw.text: I stumbled upon this restaurant on Yelp, not reading any of its history. I made a reservation for one, since I was traveling solo and needed motivation to leave my hotel :) This is French-European style cooking, so there's lots of butter. I sat down and was served green olives, my absolute favorite food. I knew I wanted a wine, and I couldn't decide. The bartender was more than happy to help with my decision, and in fact helped me to pick one of the best wines I've ever had. Then the bread and butter came - of course this did not disappoint.For my main course, I ordered the Turbot. It had a pureed broccoli spread on the side that was so innovated and tasty. The portion was just enough for me, but if you have a bigger appetite, you may want a starter or a heartier entree.I always have room for dessert, so I ordered the raspberry souffle with lemon gelato.  It was so light and fluffy, with just the right hint of flavor and sweetness. I had to beg the waitress to take it away so I wouldn't finish it.I would come back here over and over again. The fact that it had a Michelin star previously made me wonder why they still don't! Service, Food, Decor, Drinks, and overall Experience were all impeccable.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom. Door on the left. I mistakenly tried to pry open the one on the right thinking the one on the left was merely a window.
Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom. Dessert after dessert.
Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom. Raspberry souffle with lemon gelato

6RQevoApFzgxbEUxyYrzUw.text: Cozy restaurant with impeccable service and delicate food, cooked to perfection, with subtle flavors. Fresh warm bread, melt in your mouth venison and chocolate soup desert all leaving you wish you could eat more! Our family decided to make it a must on every London stop.

S5NeBT3QCBzmI7iRNGTo6g.text: We went there for our wedding anniversary. Perfect place for a romantic dinner. The food is absolutely perfect. Beautiful dishes.the service is fantastic! Love it

dEOhDvpD9fB6qNdHQHPx6A.text: This is my first time for visiting London and I decided to try some good restaurants in the big city. I reserved a table before I went. The food is OK --not outstanding and not even at the quality of one star Michelin. The service was Terrible!! Terrible!!The waitress even did not know how to introduce the menu and even not stop by asking if I need water or not. Just let me wait for there 10 minutes. In the end, I told the waitress that I finished and ready to pay bills. Another 15 minutes to wait!! It's not a busy time!! 2:00 pm ish. How come this can be one star Micheline restaurant!!???@@ after this experience, I did not fully trust evaluations from Micheline. There are a bunch of good restaurants around London. Do not recommend my friends to go to this one.

EKFpmN1B86SI69iLVeXtGA.text: Delicious. Special. It used to be a gentlemans club I think, so the interior still retains some features which makes it interesting! The food is creative and hits the spot.

alYXiipExx12EWeCJWF43A.text: Wild Honey is an amazing establishment with innovative delicacies, friendly staff, and a posh but cozy interior. The waiter struck just the right balance of being attentive without suffocating. The food was delicious and creative. They've found novel ways to kick traditional fare up a notch. The wine list is exceptional (although several bottles were well beyond our budget). The space has a window at the front, which lends a bit of light to the moody, charming interior. I was truly touched by the small samples the waiter brought from the kitchen too. When I joked in passing I couldn't fit any dessert, he brought a small plate of chocolate treats anyway. Nice touch!

MuZesm-M9BMPPy890OUolw.text: have tried several mechelin restaurants in London and wild honey is my favorite. The dessert wild honey is  extremely amazing! Love the starter including crab and tried beef tartare also, love love. Love the atmosphere there. Very relaxing and intimate.

Fcyf9rjiynVinve3mwlE1Q.text: Good flavors.  Each course is well prepared and plated.  Service can be a bit erratic, but is generally good.  Nice location across from St. George's Hanover Square.

78sDgaDKZhHNCrmW7m60uQ.text: We went in January with friends and were a bit disappointed.  For the price and with a Michelin star, one goes in with expectations high.  It was OK in the end, but it was a bumpy ride and I probably won't drop that kind of dosh there again.My food was nice, but not amazing (main:  venison).  A couple of my friends weren't impressed with their pheasant, saying it was boring.  The starters were the star of the show, but they rushed it to us while we were still eating our amuse-bouches.  Dessert was nice.  Cheese course disappointing; mainly due to 1 type of oat cracker and an unpleasant onion chutney.The service was all over the place, until I had a word with the manager, and he made it up to us by personally taking care of us (and a couple of other things).  I was grateful for the turnaround at the end.Cool art on the walls.

uEphGteHkMgsf4xbHBg33w.text: I disagree with all negative reviews about food been served cold. The place is sick. Before coming to the restaurant I spent a week around the area and almost thought British food is only about fish and chips - wrong. This place offers impeccable sophisticated food.We ordered salmon as an appetizer. It was melting in my mouth. I only wish the portion would be endless. As main entrees we ordered roast saddle and braised shoulder of rabbit, white beans, aubergine and Bouillabaisse 'traditional Marseille style. The rabbit was so juicy and so tasteful. It came with French style baked potatoes and that  one was probably  the best in my life.Bouillabaisse 'traditional Marseille style had really fresh fish and the portion was generous. What was special about this entree is that they bring you fish and vegetables on one plate and souses and soup separately and you can make it how you prefer.Not to mention that the selection of wine they offer is tremendous. You can get a bottle of nice French/Spanish wine starting at $30 or about 18 pounds. The also have a great selection of cheese.We finished our night with their out of control honey ice cream and raspberry warm cake with ice cream. I was in heaven after trying both.I recommend going  for their special, which is £22.50 and you get one appetizer, entree and dessert. That deal is great and I only wish I would see it before we ordered food:)The only reason why the place is getting 4 stars is the service. Our waiter was not warm at all and would never follow up with us on our orders. However, there was another nice waiter who was so kind to offer free cheese and crackers to our daughter. If you want to go for some good food in London this place is definitely one of them.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom. Salmon appetizer
Photo of Wild Honey - London, United Kingdom. Rabbit

t7-FJbBycxyuEI6KXFtPXQ.text: The honey comb ice cream was very delicious Food was nice but had the scallops for starter and it was really dry and overcooked. Overall a bit overppriced as I have had better

5BndcvR6RveuESeC2i3qvQ.text: Beautiful restaurant and definitely worth the visit.  The  menu steps outside the norm and is beautifully presented my only criticism was that my honey ice cream had melted quite a bit by the time I got it. Still delicious though. I had the scallop that was cooked perfectly and the sea bass as a main that also was perfect and very fresh. I do think it was slightly over priced especially the starters.

KaFgVUQu7wK-QxWJ-YMZyw.text: During a short trip in London, we decided to try a new restaurant based on search and good reviews! Saturday night, we walk in a mostly empty room, over lit and no music at all. Actually it was dead silent (sort of like eating in a library; a bit awkward). The food was OK, nothing memorable, service awkard . It was one of the weirdest restaurant experiences I can remember  in any city. I decided for the first time to join yelp to get my voice out. Frankly how this place can have a michelin star is a mystery. Well I am very suspicious of all these reviews so i read the one star. I guess by now you can conclude that I do strongly not recommend this place in London.

Cq5gEqUU_uMwC5bgg8rEtw.text: Dining alone at the bar. Super friendly bartenders and knowledgeable about their cocktails and spirits. The smoked eel appetizer is heavenly and the venison main course with chestnut purée and pickled cranberries was cooked perfectly. The new old world club feel is comfortable alone, with a date or with friends.

1z0-h1-9RBt8pA_Z6TWaxA.text: Pre-theater dinner spot.I really loved this place - the food was amazing and the service was impeccable.  The one thing I found a bit odd is that there is no background music.  Now, when this place gets hopping...that is no problem at all.  BUT, when you are eating dinner at 530pm so you can get to the theater on time, AND you are eating alone...its really creepy.  You just sit there and eat in complete silence whilst all the staff just stares at you.  Super awkward.

wM4r20e-fS5LLImiuruPXg.text: Let me start by saying I plan to go back to Wild Honey as I feel I might have just hit it on a bad day. My expectations were very very high when I walked in for lunch and was greeted by the friendly hostess. I am a HUGE fan of Arbutus, its Boho chic sister restaurant in Soho. Wild Honey feels like the successful older brother with the office job. The Mayfair space is more on the traditional side, yet not stuffy, perhaps a sort of more youthful take on classic. I loved the brasserie style bar you pass as you walk in on your way to the tables in the back. The tables were very close together, and I think here is where I started to feel a bit put off. Once you squeeze in (nearly knocking the drink of person at the table next to you), you realize you are practically sitting with the people next to you. You can hear their entire conversation, try as you might to block out the fact that they can't decide whether to go on holiday in Australia or go skiing in Switzerland and whether or not the children's nanny should come along too and if so is it OK for her to fly economy while the family is in Club class. Oh dear. If that wasn't enough they had to have a lengthy discuss between themselves whether or not it would be ok to have a glass of wine with lunch or if that might upset the pre holiday diet. I found the menu a similar continental flair, yet a bit more fussy, to the one at Arbutus. I ordered a starter that was unremarkable, and then a fish dish which was quite good, yet somehow lacking. I might have ordered wrong in the sense that I was probably more in the mood for meat since when I saw the plate of the person across from me it looked incredibly tantalizing. On that note I will say, go check it out as I plan to go again. Watch this space for an update...
